content.title: Takayasu Arteritis - Comprehensive Overview
content.summary: Large vessel vasculitis predominantly affecting young women, causing inflammation and stenosis of the aorta and major branch vessels, also known as 'pulseless disease.'

definitions.definition: Chronic granulomatous panarteritis affecting the aorta and its major branches, pulmonary arteries, and coronary arteries, typically occurring in women under age 40.

Anatomic classification: Type I (branches of aortic arch), Type IIa (ascending aorta/arch/branches), Type IIb (Type IIa + descending thoracic), Type III (descending thoracic/abdominal/renals), Type IV (abdominal aorta/renals), Type V (entire aorta and branches).

key_concepts.explanation: Systemic/pre-pulseless phase: constitutional symptoms, elevated ESR/CRP, fatigue, arthralgias. Occlusive/pulseless phase: diminished pulses, claudication, hypertension, bruits, end-organ ischemia. Phases may overlap.

Upper extremity claudication, absent pulses (pulseless disease), blood pressure discrepancy (>10mmHg between arms), carotid bruits, renovascular hypertension, aortic regurgitation, stroke, and cardiac failure.
NIH criteria for active disease: systemic features, elevated ESR/CRP, new vascular abnormalities, new ischemic symptoms. PET-CT may show arterial wall FDG uptake in active inflammation.

Surgery should be performed during quiescent phase if possible. Operating during active inflammation increases anastomotic complications. Pre-operative disease control with immunosuppression is critical.

evidence.finding: ≥3 of 6 criteria: age <40, claudication, decreased brachial pulse, BP difference >10mmHg, bruit, angiographic abnormality

evidence.citation: Ogino et al., Surgical Outcomes Review, 2002
evidence.finding: 10-year surgical patency rates >80% when performed in quiescent phase with appropriate bypass conduit selection

clinical_pearls: Consider Takayasu in any young woman with unexplained hypertension, absent pulses, or arm claudication
ESR/CRP may normalize despite active disease - imaging (PET-CT, MRA) may be more sensitive
Use prosthetic grafts with caution - autologous conduit preferred due to tissue fragility
Avoid endovascular interventions during active disease - high restenosis rates
Post-surgical surveillance is lifelong - late stenosis and aneurysm formation occur
learning_objectives: Apply the Numano classification to describe disease extent
Recognize the two clinical phases of Takayasu arteritis
Assess disease activity using NIH criteria
State the importance of quiescent disease before surgical intervention
Compare surgical approaches for different anatomic patterns
